did.head: Summary Information
did.abstract: Consists of individual items acquired separately either as a gift or purchase from a variety of sources, relating to the War of 1812.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The materials in the War of 1812 manuscript collection were acquired principally during the period 1942 to 1969 from a variety of sources through the cooperative efforts of historians, librarians, and booksellers. Indiana University history professors Logan Esary, R.C. Buley, Donald F. Carmony, Chase C. Mooney, and O.O. Winther all supported the acquisition of books and manuscripts that would create an in-depth collection to support serious scholarship. With their librarian colleagues Cecil K. Byrd and Geneva Warner, they scanned book catalogues, sent out inquiries, and followed up on leads to manuscript collections. The bookseller partners in the development of the War of 1812 collections included John S. Van E. Kohn and Wright Howes, but one man deserves special credit for his ongoing engagement in the building of the collection: the Crawfordsville, Indiana, bookman R. E. Banta. Of particular note, Banta orchestrated the acquisition in 1943 of the important collection of manuscripts assembled by Forest G. Sweet.

The manuscripts described here are one part of a larger body of materials that make up the War of 1812 collections at the Lilly Library which includes books, broadsides, prints, periodicals, newspapers, and other manuscript collections. Highlights of the books and manuscripts are described in the exhibition catalogue, An exhibit to commemorate the one hundred fiftieth anniversary of the beginning of the War of 1812, published by the library in 1962.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the series. Each item is described separately. Descriptions include indexing terms; names are often followed by occupation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The War of 1812 mss. collection consists of materials dating from 1776 to 1879 relating to the War of 1812. It includes correspondence, log books, legal documents, diaries, speeches, letter copybooks, orderly books, and receipts.

altformavail.head: Additional Physical Form Available
altformavail.p: Also available as digital reproductions. All items in this collection have been digitized except for items which are reproductions of original manuscripts held in other institutions.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in IUCAT, the IU Libraries' online catalog. Materials about related topics, persons or places can be found by searching the catalog using these terms.

extref.subject: New Orleans, Battle of, New Orleans, La., 1815.
River Raisin, Battle of the, Monroe, Mich., 1813.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Received from numerous sources at various times. Accession information is given for the majority of entries.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], War of 1812 mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

origination.persname: Bacon, Mrs. Lydia B. (Stetson), (Mrs. Josiah Bacon), 1786-1853

scopecontent.p: Journal, May 9, 1811-August 19, 1812: journey with her husband Lieutenant Josiah Bacon, a quartermaster of the 4th regiment, United States infantry, from Boston to Vincennes, including a description of the boat trip down the Ohio River from Pittsburgh and up the Wabash River to Vincennes; experiences at Vincennes while awaiting the return of her husband from the Tippecanoe campaign; experiences on return journey to Massachusetts, including being twice made a prisoner of war by the British and witnessing the siege of Detroit and General Hull’s surrender there.

list.item: Photostat made from the original manuscript owned by the New York Historical Society. 1949.

Printed in Mary Mazeppa Crawford’s Mrs. Lydia B. Bacon’s Journal, `1811-1812', Indiana Magazine of History, XL; 367-86, December 1944: XLI: 59-79, March 1945; printed with revision in the The Biography of Mrs. Lydia B. Bacon … Boston, Massachusetts Sabbath School Society, 1856.

scopecontent.p: United States To Lord Balgray, Edinburgh. Extracts of a letter: It is true that I should with great regret leave this Country without first having had an understanding with some One or more of the persons, in power or of influence as to the line of conduct this Government would pursue in the case of certain events which probably may Occur in the United States … no channel of approach is open me … It is a Sad Spectacle that two nations whom every Motive of interest and policy invite to Union, should waste their time`, their resources and their energies in vile, unprofitable discord.

acqinfo.p: Purchased. Francis Edwards, London, England. 1948.

scopecontent.p: Log book diary on board the brig Margaret of Philadelphia and as a prisoner of war of the British: sailed from Philadelphia bound for Gibraltar, Mar. 21, 1812; anchored at Gibraltar, May 3, 1812; sightseeing tour of vicinity; informed that U.S had declared war against Great Britain and taken prisoner by H.M.S. Saint Juan, Aug. 8, 1812; sailed, Nov. 22, 1812, on Devant, British man-of-war bound for Portsmouth, England; Devant captured a letter of marque, prize to the privateer Paul Jones of New York, Jan. 29, 1813; captured a French lugger in English channel, Feb. 6, 1813; ran into Sheerness Harbor and 130 men set to Chatham prison, Feb. 24, 1813; Ward put on board Nassau with nearly 800 American prisoners, Feb. 25, 1813; exchange of prisoners; Ward in group exchanged for Java’s crew; transferred to cartel Admittance, May 7, 1813; got underway for America, May 18, 1813.

acqinfo.p: Purchased. A.W. Paine, New York, New York. 1953

list.item: Approved bill of Richard Tarwin for apprehending two deserters. Aug. 26, 1812. Autographed document signed. 1 p 14 cm.
Order to pay bill of T.C. Barker & Co. for medical supplies. Aug. 26, 1812. Autographed document signed. 2 p. 12 cm.
Order to pay James Audrain and Samuel Wells one hundred dollars for certain services. Aug. 27, 1812. Autographed document signed. 1 p. 17 cm.
Order to pay Antonio Bonde $2.50 for five deerskins to be used for drum heads. Bond’s receipt on verso. Sept. 23, 1812. Autographed document signed. 2 p. 6 cm.
Approved bill of Ezekiel Hutchinson for damages to his farm by troops encamped there, Oct. 6, 1812. Autographed document signed. 1 p. 22 cm.

Certificate that a dun horse was lost on a forced march from St. Mary’s to Fort Wayne, approved for payment to David Richardson. Also signed by Charles Steward Todd. Autographed document signed. 1 p. 16 cm.
Order to pay Samuel Weathers, a waggoner twenty-five dollars. Autographed document signed. 1 p. 16 cm.

scopecontent.p: Dispatch book. Contains thirty-four dispatches to Thomas Humphrey Cushing, William Eustis, William Henry Harrison, Return Jonathan Meigs, James Morrison, Isaac Shelby, and others. It is a day by day account of his campaign dealing with the sufferings and hardships of the soldiers for want of supplies of food and clothing; the cramped position of commanders of the armies; and the general incompetence and indifference in so many of the person responsible for the state of affairs.

scopecontent.p: Bulloch, Georgia. To Charles Harris, Savannah, Georgia. To Charles Harris, Savannah, Georgia. The situation of the people of Florida is indeed distressing and ought to be immediately relieved - as it is easy to foresee if this is not done, that the Southern Country … will be in a continual state of alarm. United States participation in War of 1812 justified, but should have been postponed until the country was more sufficiently prepared; place of Florida sufficiently prepared; place of Florida in the war.

scopecontent.p: Journal as lieutenant on board the H.M.S. Bacchante while on service in the Adriatic and the Mediterranean from April 3, 1813-June 11, 1814, and in American waters from July 31, 1814-Mary 25, 1815, and on board the H.M.S. Sybelle during May 3-June 14, 1819.

acqinfo.p: Purchased. Alfred W. Paine, Wolfpits Road, Bethel, Connecticut. 1960.

list.item: An account in Saumarez’ own hand.

A visit to the prize ship Chesapeake is noted Aug. 19, 1814; an account of the Penobscot Bay expedition is reported Aug. 31-Sept. 27, 1814; the capture of the privateer McDonough is recorded Nov. 1, 1814.
Having supervised the dismantling of his ship, Saumarez arrived in London, July 22, 1815.

In May 1816 he received an award from the Royal Human Society with an accompanying citation: …meritorious and highly laudable conduct of Lt. R. Saumarez of HSM Baccante in voluntarily risking his own like… to save that of Robt Taylor a seaman…
Following a tour of Europe, Saumarez returned to the West Indies to serve on H.M.S. Sybell May 3-June 14, 1819.
No entries for Sept. 1817-May 30, 1819 except a single entry for Apr. 10, 1818.

Cochrane proceed to Halifax to get supplies and then proceed to New Orleans; Malcolm in command at Chesapeake and sail south Oct. 10; Cockburn to make raids upon the coast of Carolinas and Georgia to prevent those states from sending aid to Louisiana.

scopecontent.p: Niagara Falls, New York. To William Leete Stone. Acknowledging receipt of mss. sheets of Stone’s intended biography of Red Jacket, which contain a notice of the repulse of a detachment of British troops under Col. Bishop, at Black Rock, in July 1813; being the first occasion on which the Indians were actually engaged in battle, as auxiliaries of the Americans; and the remainder comprising an account of the march and operations of the American Army under Gen. Brown, from the time of their entering Canada on the third of July 1814, until shortly after the battle of Chippewa; account of those two engagements, with the request that Stone, accept this as a substitute for the sheets you have me.

acqinfo.p: Purchased. Midland Rare Book company, Mansfield, Ohio. 1948.

list.item: Revised version of mss. p. 2, last paragraph to p. 18, paragraph l, inclusive, printed in William Lette Stone. The Life and times of Red Jacket, or Sa-go-ye-wat-ha … (New York, 1841) pp. 252-276. Stone, Ibid., note, p. 2247, gives credit to Porter for this portion of his book. Revised version of mss. pp. A-B printed in Stone, Ibid., pp. 241-243.

Dauphin Island, pp. 27 (i.e. 33)-31 (i.e. 37)
Havana pp. 32 (i.e. 39)-36 (i.e. 43)
Departure for and arrival in England, pp. 36 (i.e. 43)-40 (i.e. 48)
